body:
Problem:  ext_messages is implemented to mimic the message grid
          implementation w.r.t. scrolling messages, clearing scrolled
          messages, hit-enter-prompts and replacing a previous message.
          Meanwhile, an ext_messages UI may not be implemented in a way
          where these events are wanted. Moreover, correctness of these
          events even assuming a "scrolled message" implementation
          depends on fragile "currently visible messages" global state,
          which already isn't correct after a previous message was
          supposed to have been overwritten (because that should not only
          happen when `msg_scroll == false`).

Solution: 
- No longer attempt to keep track of the currently visible
            messages: remove the `msg_ext(_history)_visible` variables.
            UIs may remove messages pre-emptively (timer based), or never
            show messages that don't fit a certain area in the first place.
- No longer emit the `msg(_history)_clear` events to clear
            "scrolled" messages. This opens up the `msg_clear` event to
            be emitted when messages should actually be cleared (e.g.
            when the screen is cleared). May also be useful to emit before
            the first message in an event loop cycle as a hint to the UI
            that it is a new batch of messages (vim._extui currently
            schedules an event to determine that).
- Set `replace_last` explicitly at the few callsites that want
            this to be set to true to replace an incomplete status message.
- Don't store a "keep" message to be re-emitted.

Resolve #20416

comment_data.body:
The guidance is for UIs to determine themselves when to clear messages🫣 @xiyaowong already seems to have the right idea.

If a UI opens a new window to show messages, it makes sense to just clear messages after a few seconds. If a UI shows messages in a persistent area (cmdline), it makes sense to "clear" messages at the start of a new batch of messages. extui uses the next eventloop cycle to determine this (vim.schedule), like the message grid implementation does.

comment_regular_data.body:
Draft PR mainly intended to discuss the posed problem-solution statement.

From #20416, not clearing/re-emitting "still visible" messages seems wanted. 

Not emitting the hit-return message also seems fair game. The handler can decide and trigger a hit-enter prompt itself (e.g. based on the message kind or text height of the message).

Might also want to reconsider the `msg_show->replace_last` parameter. Nvim deciding whether a message should be replaced seems strange, although I suppose it is only a suggestion. The handler may show different message kinds in different UI elements.

Looks nice!

> Not emitting the hit-return message also seems fair game. The handler can decide and trigger a hit-enter prompt itself (e.g. based on the message kind or text height of the message).

Also sounds nice.

What are the downsides?

> What are the downsides?

From my POV there aren't any, besides changing behavior which clients may be relying on (not sure who else to ping to confirm that). I would say a client is in a better position to decide whether clearing/prompting is required than to take these suggestions from Nvim.
we can merge it early in 0.11 development cycle and find out

> we can merge it early in 0.11 development cycle and find out

Given that the 0.11 dev cycle is underway, should this be merged?
Needs a rebase. What is the plan here (and for message grid rework generally)? Are we confident about this being ready for 0.11, or do we want to bump to 0.12?

I'm personally a big fan of this PR.

Will reduce `ui_attach` events a lot. In Noice I currently need to do all sorts of work-arounds and duplicate event detection to make sure the ui doesn't get spammed.

> duplicate event detection to make sure the ui doesn't get spammed.

I still haven't actually found a clear reproducer where `keep_msg` is responsible for this, do you have one? As mentioned in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/20416#issuecomment-2484076484, we may still want to remove `keep_msg`. But I think the scope of this PR is too big, and I've since found that `replace_last` actually is useful sometimes (I think noice also uses it?).

Can still go through with at least disabling `keep_msg` and the `hit-enter-prompt` under the given reasoning. But I'm no longer sure the breaking event changes here are worth it (those can easily be ignored after all).

> Yeah recursive/redundant events were already reduced in various other PRs.

Should've checked that indeed :)

> Does this patch improve that?

Nope, still the same. `cmdline_show` events.
Depending on how you redraw, #32237 might help @folke. This completely eliminates redundant cmdline events for me, just a complete redraw (`<C-L>, :mode`) still re-emits the cmdline state.

After looking into this again to resolve #34035, I found that "currently visible messages", which is used to determine when to emit these events, can already get out-of-sync with what it would be on the message grid. The fact that it doesn't work properly in it's current form increased my confidence in making a breaking change here (are there any UIs that tried to implement this exactly as the message grid or do they all just implement `msg_set_pos` events?), so I've rebased and reworked this.
